Message.Title: Lenovo still interested in BlackBerry buyout
Message.Msg: Lenovo CEO Yang Yuanqing once again reaffirmed today it is interested in a potential BlackBerry deal. The CEO admitted that a buyout might be on the cards as the company seeks to gain more traction in the western mobile market. These comments come after CFO Wong Wai Ming told Bloomberg in January that *Lenovo was "looking at all opportunities,"* one of which was BlackBerry. Watch the stock today, before the news starts spreading.

Topic.Title: XBOX announcement is at 1 PM today

Message.Msg: Stock is going higher with strong momentum eventually. Sometimes on these announcements professional traders do a buy on the rumor and sell on the news. So be careful today. It is always the hardest time to buy on the day of a major announcement. All it takes is some firm indicating they are discounted and their friends sell it off (planned ahead of time). Professional day traders watch for this and are ready to take it down if the opportunity exists. On the other hand the news may be so good that is surpasses all of "their" not mine expectations. Then the stock will jump .75 to $1.50 on the news and keep rising. It is really the most difficult buying time for me at least because of the vultures circling for the "DISSAPOINTMENT EFFECT" or buy on the rumor sell on the news. Hope for the best, I am long and strong. Never sold since the beginning.

Message.Title: Ebix To Deliver Multimedia Health Content on Bing....
Message.Msg: Ebix, Inc. announced that the company's A.D.A.M. multimedia health content will be included on Bing, Microsoft Corp.'s search engine. More than 59 percent of all U.S. adults go online to search for health information.* Now, when people search on Bing, they will find information from the US National Library of Medicine which licenses its data from Ebix. A.D.A.M. multimedia health content provides access to the authoritative Health Answer from the National Institute of Health and other public and private health-related organizations. A.D.A.M.'s content provides health consumers with a comprehensive online health information database complete with thousands of physician-written and reviewed articles covering conditions, procedures, treatments, surgeries, and tests in an easy-to-navigate format. The visually rich content features award-winning medical illustrations, HD videos and interactive tools. Since the content is available in HTML5, consumers can view the content and videos on any device, including mobile phones and tablets. The content is available in English and Spanish. Jim Retel, Ebix Vice President - A.D.A.M. said, "We are excited to be working with Bing to deliver content that will be accessible to millions of consumers who are actively seeking reliable health information. We believe that the diverse range of health information seekers on the Web today will benefit from our expertise in communicating important health information in a way that is understandable and actionable."

Message.Title: I love my new Samsung Google Chromebook!

It cost 1/4 the price of an Ultrabook or Surface Pro. And best of all, NO Windows 8 Metro!!! Hooray!!!

Message.Title: Unions at odds with Obama health care LOL
Message.Msg: Labor unions are breaking with President Obama on ObamaCare. Months after the president’s reelection, a variety of unions are publicly balking at how the administration plans to implement the landmark law. They warn that unless there are changes, the results could be catastrophic The United Food and Commercial Workers International Union (UFCW) — a 1.3 million-member labor group that twice endorsed Obama for president — is very worried about how the reform law will affect its members’ healthcare plans. Last month, the president of the United Union of Roofers, Waterproofers and Allied Workers released a statement calling “for repeal or complete reform of the Affordable Care Act.” UNITE HERE, a prominent hotel workers’ union, and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters are also pushing for changes. In a new op-ed published in The Hill, UFCW President Joe Hansen homed in on the president’s speech at the 2009 AFL-CIO convention. Obama at the time said union members could keep their insurance under the law, but Hansen writes “that the president’s statement to labor in 2009 is simply not true for millions of workers.” Republicans have long attacked Obama’s promise that “nothing in this plan will require you to change your coverage or your doctor.” But the fact that unions are now noting it as well is a clear sign that supporters of the law are growing anxious about the law’s implementation.

Message.Msg: I have been a HUGE Sony fan since the PS1 and usually ignored anything related to Xbox... I can say for the first time in my gaming existence I look to Xbox one as the leader of innovation and leadership in the gaming world. I was blown away by the reveal today and I truly believe for the first time that Microsoft has got Sony beat this generation and it all comes down to what is backing it. Microsofts cloud computing is what sold me on this product that I wasn't even remotely interested in yesterday. I know this company is much bigger than their xbox division, but their vision for the cloud and their reveal of the new xbox is what made me buy some shares today. I'll be holding onto this for a long time as I see them eventually beating out Amazon in the cloud business as well as furthering themselves from the competition in the console wars.

Message.Title: This happens with all major announcements for all co's now.
Message.Msg: Sometimes it is naked short selling or certain investors all know they are going to dump it and short hoping to pull it down. Most announcements disappoint. This one did not. It was on the line of the first Iphone type presentation. He blew it by being nervous and allowing a mere 20 seconds on how you can browse the internet at the same time as watching a football game or playing a game. He also did not elaborate on how you will input the internet use or internet searches when a show is playing. You cannot do a voice search when a loud game is going. You will need a little 7 " tablet or a Nokia Lumia 928, 925 or 920. You can also watch the entertainment on the phone. The phone interaction was not made clear. I realize he had to move to the next frame. I think the gamers are an easy sell and they need to target the adv. towards the entertainment and phone searching on the tv, blu ray, Skype, controlling your cable and selecting and finding shows easily.

Message.Title: problems with Xbox One
Message.Msg: #1. Console will not function without Kinect connected. So it's not really a portable device. Have to haul everything around to move to another room. A gaming party would be a problem with all those Kinects reading everyones movements. Anybody who has no interest in what the Kinect offers is forced to have it take up space in the room. #2. Game installation is required, and used games will require a new license to be purchased. Not good. Just look at Gamestop's stock. #3. The thing is big. Not sleak. Plus you must the Kinect attached. Not something I want sitting around my TV set.

Topic.Title: Hicks point finger at Hillary for Benghazi

Message.Msg: The former diplomats inform PJM the new revelations concentrate in two areas — what Ambassador Chris Stevens was actually doing in Benghazi and the pressure put on General Carter Ham, then in command of U.S. Africa Command (AFRICOM) and therefore responsible for Libya, not to act to protect jeopardized U.S. personnel. Stevens’ mission in Benghazi, they will say, was to buy back Stinger missiles from al-Qaeda groups issued to them by the State Department, not by the CIA. Such a mission would usually be a CIA effort, but the intelligence agency had opposed the idea because of the high risk involved in arming “insurgents” with powerful weapons that endanger civilian aircraft. Hillary Clinton still wanted to proceed because, in part, as one of the diplomats said, she wanted “to overthrow Gaddafi on the cheap.” This left Stevens in the position of having to clean up the scandalous enterprise when it became clear that the “insurgents” actually were al-Qaeda – indeed, in the view of one of the diplomats, the same group that attacked the consulate and ended up killing Stevens.

Message.Title: New Xbox Faces Wider Range of Competition
Message.Msg: Google it. Quoting: "REDMOND, Wash. — When Microsoft began selling its last video-game console nearly eight years ago, there was no iPad, smartphones had keyboards and Facebook was mainly for college students. "But it is against those devices and services, all of which have transformed the games business, that the new Xbox that Microsoft introduced on Tuesday will compete. "The new device, the Xbox One, is a big gamble by Microsoft that it can re-establish the living room as the place where people can get the best gaming experience, with the most eye-popping graphics and innovative methods for controlling games. It is also an effort by Microsoft to step up its push to make the Xbox an all-purpose device for getting to online video."

Topic.Title: XBOX ONE - The Day The World Changed Forever....

Message.Msg: Microsoft TV Technologies enables the rapid development of digital and analog TV applications on the Windows platform. Microsoft TV Technologies provides built-in software support for all major analog and digital broadcast standards, including ATSC, DVB, NTSC, PAL, SECAM and more. Full support is also provided for IP data services and closed captioning. Applications based on Microsoft TV Technologies are de-coupled from the details of tuning and are therefore network-independent. This means that the same application can be used with an analog terrestrial or cable broadcast, a ATSC terrestrial broadcast, a DVB-S network, or any other network type for which support may be added in the future by Microsoft or a third party.

Topic.Title: IRS OFFICIAL TO INVOKE FIFTH AMENDMENT

Message.Msg: Top IRS official will invoke the Fifth Amendment in congressional hearing about tea party targeting program PUBLISHED: 16:14 EST, 21 May 2013 | UPDATED: 16:51 EST, 21 May 2013 The Los Angeles Times reported Tuesday afternoon that Lois Lerner, who heads up the Internal Revenue Service's tax-exempt division, plans to invoke the Fifth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution in a hearing Wednesday before the House Committee on Oversight and Government Affairs. The Fifth Amendment provides that U.S. citizens may not be compelled to offer testimony if telling the truth would incriminate them. Lerner's defense lawyer, William W. Taylor III, wrote to the committee on Tuesday that his client would refuse to answer questions related to who from the white House directed his client to target to conservative nonprofit organizations that applied for tax-exempt status beginning in 2010.
